[[Image:VMware Workstation.png|300px|thumb|[[VMware Workstation]] running [[Ubuntu]], on Windows, an example of platform virtualization]]
In [[computing]], '''platform virtualization''' is a term that refers to the [[abstraction]] of computer resources. Virtualization hides the physical characteristics of computing resources from their users, be they [[application]]s, or [[end user]]s.<ref>{{ cite web | last = Turban | first = E | coathors = King D, Lee J, Viehland D | date = 2008 | title = Electronic Commerce A Managerial Perspective | edition = 5th edition | publisher = Prentice-Hall | chapter = Ch19 | pages = P27 | url = http://wps.prenhall.com/wps/media/objects/5073/5195381/pdf/Online_Chapter_19.pdf }}; {{ cite web | url = http://www-03.ibm.com/industries/education/doc/content/resource/thought/3371378110.html | title = Virtualization in education | publisher = [[IBM]] }}</ref> The term has been widely used since the [[1960s]].
In [[computing]], '''platform virtualization''' is a term that refers to the [[abstraction]] of computer resources. Virtualization hides the physical characteristics of computing resources from their users, be they [[application]]s, or [[end user]]s.<ref>{{ cite web | last = Turban | first = E | coathors = King D, Lee J, Viehland D | date = 2008 | title = Electronic Commerce A Managerial Perspective | edition = 5th edition | publisher = Prentice-Hall | chapter = Ch19 | pages = P27 | url = http://wps.prenhall.com/wps/media/objects/5073/5195381/pdf/Online_Chapter_19.pdf }}; {{ cite web | url = http://www-03.ibm.com/industries/education/doc/content/resource/thought/3371378110.html | title = Virtualization in education | publisher = [[IBM]] }}</ref> The term has been widely used since the [[1960s]].
